revision.text:
[[Image:Jacques Balsan.jpg|thumb|right|Jacques Balsan]] '''Louis Jacques Balsan''' (September 16, 1868 – November 4, 1956) was a French aviator and industrialist, born at [[Châteauroux]] (Indre) in 1868, who was the second husband of society beauty [[Consuelo Vanderbilt]], Duchess of Marlborough. He married her immediately after her divorce from the [[9th Duke of Marlborough]] in 1921.<ref name="JBObit1956"/>
==Early life== Balsan was born on September 16, 1868 in [[Châteauroux]], [[France]]. He was the son of [[Auguste Balsan]] and Marie ([[née]] Dupuytren). Among his siblings was brother was [[Étienne Balsan]], the first patron of [[Coco Chanel]],<ref name="D'Hauterive">{{cite book |last1=D'Hauterive |first1=M. Borel |title=Annuaire De La Noblesse De France et Des Maisons Souveraines De L'Europe, Volume 44 |date=1888 |publisher=Typographie De E. Plon, Nourrit |location=[[Paris]] |page=245 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=blwoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA245&lpg=PA245 |accessdate=17 September 2018}}</ref> and sister, Viscountess Villeneuve de Bargemont of [[Davenescourt]], France.<ref name="JBObit1956"/>
Through his mother, he was descended from [[Guillaume Dupuytren]], the [[anatomist]] and [[surgery|surgeon]] who treated [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]] and, today, is best known today for his description of [[Dupuytren's contracture]], which is named after him and which he first operated on in 1831 and published in ''[[The Lancet]]'' in 1834.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dupuytren|first=Guillaume|date=May 10, 1834|journal=The Lancet|title=Clinical Lectures on Surgery|volume=22|issue=558|pages=222–5|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(02)77708-8}}</ref>
Jacques Balsan came from a manufacturing family who created and run [[Balsan (Company)]] which supplied the French Army with uniforms from the time of [[Napoleon]] onwards which were the origin of the famous cloth "the blue horizon". The family's textile factories were situated at [[Châteauroux]].<ref name="1921Engagement"/>
==Career== At the age of 24, Jacques Balsan entered the family business and traveled the world, buying wool.
Passionate about ballooning, in September 1900, while in the balloon ''St. Louis'' that was inflated with [[illuminating gas]], he remained aloft for 39 hours and nine minutes.<ref name="JBObit1956"/> Later that same month, he earned the record for the highest altitude flight at the "[[Exposition Universelle (1900)|Exposition Universelle]]", by rising to a height of 8,558 meters;<ref>[http://aviation.maisons-champagne.com/dir.php?centre=04-bio-balsan&menu=11 Champagne|Berceau De L'Aviation Du Monde, Jacques Balsan]</ref> the following month traveling over 1,345 kilometers (roughly 850 miles) from [[Vincennes]] to [[Opoczno|Opoezno]], [[Russia]].<ref name="JBObit1956"/>
A pioneer of flying, he bought his first aircraft in 1905, a [[Octave_Chanute|Chanute]]-type glider, and an airplane in 1909 and obtained a Number 22 licence to pilot aircraft. He also took part in aviation experiments with the [[Wright brothers]] in [[Biarritz]] and in 1910, constructed his own small plane.<ref name="JBObit1956"/> In February 1910, in his [[Blériot Aéronautique|Blériot]] [[monoplane]], he won the "[[The meeting of Heliopolis|Le Prix d'Héliopolis]]" (in [[Egypt]]).
===Military service=== During [[World War I]], he helped organize the [[Lafayette Escadrille]] along with [[William K. Vanderbilt]] and Dr. Edmund Gros, also a founder of the [[American Hospital of Paris]] and organizer of the [[AFS Intercultural Programs#WWI|American Ambulance Field Service]].<ref name="JBObit1956"/> Later, [[Michel-Joseph Maunoury|General Maunoury]] gave him charge of the aerial [[reconnaissance]] of the site of the [[First Battle of the Marne]]. In 1918, he went to London as chief of the [[French Air Force]] mission. By the end of the War, he was promoted to the rank of [[Lieutenant colonel]].<ref name="1921Engagement"/>
During [[World War II]], he joined the [[Free French]] forces in London, taking part in the operations that liberated southern France.<ref name="JBObit1956"/>
==Personal life== [[File:JB-125-1930-Jacques & Consuelo-St Georges Motel.jpg|thumb|right|Jacques and Consuelo at [[Saint-Georges-Motel|St-Georges-Motel]], between 1930 and 1935.]] Balsan first saw and immediately fell in love with wealthy American, [[Consuelo Vanderbilt]], when she was 17, before her marriage to the 9th [[Duke of Marlborough (title)|Duke of Marlborough]].<ref name="1921Engagement">{{cite news |title=VANDERBILT TROTH REPORT IS REVIVED Marlborough Duchess's Rumored Engagement to Jacques Balsan No Surprise.HE IS FRENCH SPORTSMAN Duchess Recently Bought an Estate Near Monte Carlo—Both Are Now Among Colonists on Riviera. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/02/13/112670889.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 13, 1921}}</ref> She was considered the most eligible woman of the late [[Victorian Age]]. A memorable portrait of her by [[Carolus Duran]] hangs at [[Blenheim Palace]]. Balsan married her on 4 July 1921 (when he was 52 and she was 44), after which she was styled 'Mme Jacques Balsan',<ref name="1921OffEngage">{{cite news |title=Give Notice of Coming Marriage of Col. Balsan To Consuelo, Duchess of Marlborough |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/07/03/107018544.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 3, 1921}}</ref><ref name="1921Marriage">{{cite news |title=AMERICAN DUCHESS NOW MME, BALSAN Former Wife of Marlborough Weds French Officer in Flower-Decked London Church. {{!}} MINISTER ADDRESSES BOTH {{!}} Tells Bride "God Has Brought You at Last to Peace"—Felicitates Bridegroom. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/07/05/107019561.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 5, 1921}}</ref> until her death in 1964. Known for his attentions to her, it was a very happy marriage. Consuelo wrote to her close friend [[Winston Churchill]], during [[World War II]], while Jacques worked with the [[Free French]] in [[London]], to request his special protection and safe return. Winston obligingly facilitated his safe return to America.
The Balsans were hosting Winston and Clementine Churchill in September 1939, just before the outbreak of war at their chateau [[Saint-Georges-Motel]], near [[Dreux]] north of [[Paris]]. They also owned a property in [[Èze]] (Alpes-Maritimes) where they received a number of celebrities such as the [[Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught|Duke of Connaught]], son of Queen Victoria, The Maharajah de Kapurthala and [[Charlie Chaplin]]. <ref>{{cite book|last1=Balsan|first1=Consuelo Vanderbilt|title=The glitter and the gold|date=2011|publisher=Hodder|location=London|isbn=1444730983}}</ref> Balsan supported his wife's work with French children. They lived in their ''[[hotel particulier]]'' in Paris, 9 avenue [[Avenue_Charles-Floquet|Charles-Floquet]].
[[Consuelo Vanderbilt]]'s ghosted autobiography ''The Glitter and The Gold'' refers to her time with Balsan as "gold", as opposed to the "glitter" of her earlier, aristocratic marriage. In it, she tells the story of the Balsans' daring escape from the Nazis through Spain to Portugal and eventually to America, where they lived for the rest of their lives.<ref>Stuart, Amanda Mackenzie. ''Consuelo and Alva Vanderbilt: The Story of a Daughter and Mother in the Gilded Age''. Harper Perennial, 2005.</ref>
Jacques Balsan died on November 4, 1956 at his home, 1 Sutton Place, New York City, in America.<ref name="JBObit1956">{{cite news |title=JACQUES BALSAN, AVIATION PIONEER; French Flier Is Dead at 88-- War Pilot Set Records in Balloons and Planes Volunteer in Morocco |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1956/11/06/84944145.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 6, 1956}}</ref> His death occurred less than a month after his stepson, [[Lord Ivor Churchill]], died, at the age of 57, in London on September 17, 1956.<ref name="LordIvorObit1956">{{cite news |title=LORD IVOR CHURCHILL, 57; Patron of Modern Art, a Noted Collector, Dies in London |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1956/09/18/84714276.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 18, 1956 |language=en}}</ref> Balsan was buried in [[Paris]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Newport Daily News from Newport, Rhode Island · Page 2|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/57447063/|website=Newspapers.com}}</ref> His widow died on December 6, 1964 at her home in [[Southampton, New York]] and was buried next to Lord Ivor.<ref name="CVBObit1964">{{cite news |title=Mrs. Balsan Dies; Former Vanderbilt; Mrs. Jacques Balsan, 88, Dies; Formerly Consuelo Vanderbilt |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1964/12/07/118543278.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 7, 1964 |language=en}}</ref>
==Honours==
* [[File:Legion_Honneur_Officier_ribbon.svg|50px]] Knight of the National Order of the [[Legion of Honour]] (1913 (civil) and 1925 (Officer)) * [[File:Medaille d'Outre-Mer (Coloniale) ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Colonial Medal]] (1914, Morocco) * [[File:Croix_de_Guerre_1914-1918_ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Croix de guerre 1914-1918]] (1917, with palm) * [[File:UK_Order_St-Michael_St-George_ribbon.svg|50px]] '''CMG''': [[Order of St Michael and St George|Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] (1917, United Kingdom) * [[File:Medaille_de_l'Aeronautique_ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Aeronautical Medal]] (1952, [[Santos Dumont]] promotion) * [[File:Bayon_clean.jpg|50px]] [[Commemorative medal for voluntary service in Free France]] (1946)
==See also== *[[List of pilots awarded an Aviator's Certificate by the Aéro-Club de France in 1910]]

==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Jacques Balsan''' |2= 2. [[Auguste Balsan]] |3= 3. Marie Dupuytren |4= 4. Jean-Pierre Balsan |5= 5. Élodie Martin |6= 6. Louis Dupuytren |7= 7. Adèle Léonie Jullien-Gatineau |8= 8. Pierre Balsan |9= 9. Marie-Jeanne Villaret |10= 10. Maurice Pierre Fulcran Martin |11= 11. Jenny Villaret |12= 12. Jean-Baptiste Dupuytren |13= 13. Anne Marie Catherine Thérèse Breuilh |14= 14. Martial Jullien-Gatineau |15= 15. Léonie Giroust |16= 16. Jean Antoine Balsan |17= 17. Françoise André |19= 19. Louise Villaret |24= 24. [[Guillaume Dupuytren]] |25= 25. Léonarde Breuilh |26= 26. Simon Breuilh |27= 27. Thérèse Constancin du Châtenet |28= 28. Jean Jullien-Gatineau |30= 30. Louis Amable Jacob Giroust |31= 31. Catherine-Marie Delmilhac }}

revision.text:
{{advert|date=July 2015}}
{{Infobox academic | name = Yoram Wind | image = File:JerryWind.jpg | caption = Professor Jerry Wind | othernames = Jerry (Yoram) Wind | occupation = Professor, author, consultant | spouse = | discipline = [[Marketing]] | education = {{plain list | * B Soc Sci, [[The Hebrew University]], Jerusalem, 1961 * MA, [[Stanford University]], 1963 * PhD, [[Stanford University]], 1967}} | thesis_title = | alma_mater = | workplaces = Wharton Graduate School, University of Pennsylvania | notable_works = Editor-in-chief of the ''[[Journal of Marketing]]; research on organizational buying | notable_ideas = }} '''Jerry (Yoram) Wind''' is The Lauder Professor and Professor of Marketing at [[The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]], and is the founding director of the Wharton "think tank,” The SEI Center for Advanced Studies in Management. He is internationally known for pioneering research on organizational buying behavior, market segmentation, conjoint analysis, and marketing strategy. He consults with major firms around the world, provides expert testimony in many intellectual property and antitrust cases, and has lectured in over 50 universities worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|title=JERRY (YORAM) WIND|url=https://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/profile/196/|website=Wharton, University of Pennsylvania, Marketing Department|publisher=The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
== Education == Professor Wind received his PhD from [[Stanford University]] in 1967 and his MA (1963)and B Soc Sci (1961) degrees from [[The Hebrew University]] in Jerusalem. He also received an M.A. Honors from the University of Pennsylvania.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wind|first1=Jerry|title=Yoram (Jerry) Wind)|url=https://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/profile/196/cv|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
== Career == Over the years, Wind has served as editor-in-chief of the ''[[Journal of Marketing]]'', the policy boards of the ''[[Journal of Consumer Research]]'' and ''[[Marketing Science]]'', the editorial boards and guest editor of all the major marketing journals. He led the creation of the Wharton Executive MBA Program (1974) and was founding director of both [[Lauder Institute|The Joseph H. Lauder Institute]] (1983-1988) and Wharton International Forum (1987). He led the reinvention of the Wharton MBA curriculum (1991–93) and the development of the Wharton globalization strategy (1995-1997). He is the founding director of the Wharton SEI Center for Advanced Studies in Management, whose mission is to ensure the relevance of management research and education to the evolving needs of business and society in the 21st century by partnering with global thought leaders in diverse fields to anticipate the needs of management, identify forces of change, and understand and create emerging management paradigms. Professor Wind is also the founding academic director of The Wharton Fellows Program (2000), a powerful global network of CEOs and senior executives who are committed to lifelong learning focused on transformational leadership. He is the founding director the Wharton Future of Advertising Program (2008), whose mission is to act as a catalyst for deeper insights, bolder innovation, and broader positive impact of advertising.
Professor Wind has taught MBA courses in Marketing Strategy, Marketing Methods and Applications for Business Consulting, Creativity and Interactive Marketing in the Age of the Empowered Consumer. His current research focuses on the network challenge; creativity and innovation; the future of marketing and advertising; and creating a creative organization. He is an active consultant and board member of various startups and university programs, such as the Positive Psychology Center and Integrated Product Design Committee. He also holds positions in numerous professional associations, including the Marketing Accountability Standards Board. He is a trustee of the Philadelphia Museum of Art,<ref>{{cite web|title=Board of Trustees|url=http://www.philamuseum.org/information/43-323.html?page=2|website=Philadelphia Museum of Art|publisher=Philadelphia Museum of Art|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> where he chairs its Marketing Advisory Committee and is a member of its Brand Steering Group and the Digital Age Committee. Professor Wind is the co-founder of the Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya, Israel (IDC), and since its founding in 1994, the chairman of its academic council.<ref>{{cite web|title=IDC Executive|url=http://portal.idc.ac.il/en/main/about_idc/management/pages/executive.aspx|website=IDC Herzliya|publisher=IDC Herzliya|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> Professor Wind previously served as the academic trustee of the Marketing Science Institute (1989-1995), chairman of The Institute of Management Sciences College of Marketing (1974-1975) and chancellor of The International Academy of Management (2000-2006).
Wind is The Lauder Professor and Professor of Marketing at The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. He joined the Wharton faculty in January 1967, upon receipt of his doctorate from Stanford University.
== Awards == Wind is the recipient of various awards, including the four major marketing awards- The [[Charles Coolidge Parlin]] Award (1985),<ref>{{cite web|title=Charles Coolidge Parlin Marketing Research Award|url=https://www.ama.org/AboutAMA/Pages/Parlin-Award.aspx|website=American Marketing Association|publisher=American Marketing Association|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> the [[American Marketing Association|AMA]]/Irwin Distinguished Educator Award (1993),<ref>{{cite web|title=AMA/Irwin/McGraw-Hill Distinguished Marketing Educator Award|url=https://www.ama.org/AboutAMA/Pages/AMA-Irwin-McGraw-Hill-Distinguished-Marketing-Educator-Award.aspx|website=AMA|publisher=American Marketing Association|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> the Paul D. Converse Award (1996)<ref>{{cite web|title=18th Paul D. Converse Marketing Symposium|url=http://www.business.illinois.edu/converse/previous.html|website=College of Business at Illinois|publisher=University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> and the Buck Weaver Award (2007).<ref>{{cite web|title=MIT Sloan and General Motors honor Wharton professor with Buck Weaver Award for outstanding contributions to the field of marketing|url=http://mitsloan.mit.edu/newsroom/2007-weaver.php|website=MIT Sloan Management: Newsroom|publisher=MIT Sloan School of Management|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> He is the recipient of the first Faculty Impact Award given by Wharton Alumni (1993). In 1984, he was elected as member of the Attitude Research Hall of Fame and has won a number of research awards, including two [[Alpha Kappa Psi]] Foundation awards and a recent inclusion in JAR Classics issue of 18 articles that have withstood the test of time. In 2001, he was selected as one of the 10 Grand Auteurs in Marketing and later named as the 2003 recipient of the Elsevier Science Distinguished Scholar award of the Society for Marketing Advances. In May 2004 he was awarded as Honorary Fellow of the Decade by the Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel).<ref>Sheth, J.N. (ed), ''Legends in Marketing: Yoram 'Jerry' Wind,'' Sage Publications, 2014</ref> In 2009, Wind was selected as one of the 10 Legends of Marketing and Sage published 8 edited volumes anthologizing his various publications in 2013.
== Bibliography ==
Wind is one of the most cited authors in marketing. His regular contributions to professional marketing literature include 23 books and over 250 papers, articles, and monographs encompassing the areas of marketing strategy, marketing research, new product and market development, consumer and industrial buying behavior, and global marketing.
=== Books === * 1966 ''Industrial Buying Behavior: Source Loyalty in the Purchase of Industrial Components'' * 1967 ''Industrial Buying and Creative Marketing'' with Patrick j. Robinson * 1968 ''Advertising Measurement and Decision Making'' with Homer Dalby and Irwin Gross * 1972 ''Market Segmentation (International Series in Management)'' with Ronald E. Frank and William F. Massy * 1972 ''Organizational Buying Behavior (Foundations of Marketing)'' with Frederick E. Webster * 1973 ''Multi-Attribute Decisions in Marketing: A Measurement Approach'' with Paul E. Green and Douglas Caroll * 1979 ''Marketing and Product Planning'' (in Spanish) * 1982 ''Product Policy: Concepts, Methods and Strategies (Addison-Wesley Marketing Series)'' * 1992 ''The Silverlake Project: Transformation at IBM'' with Roy A. Bauer, Emilio Collar, Victor Tang and Patrick R. Houston * 1997 ''Driving Change: How the Best Companies are Preparing for the 21st Century'' with Jeremy Main * 1999 ''Leveraging Japan: Marketing to the New Asia'' with George Fields, Hotaka Katahira and Robert E. Gunther * 2002 ''Convergence Marketing: Strategies for Reaching the New Hybrid Consumer'' with Vijay Mahajan and Robert Gunther * 2004 ''Adventures in Conjoint Analysis: A Practitioner's Guide to Trade-Off Modeling and Applications'' with Abba Krieger and Paul E. Green * 2004 ''The Power of Impossible Thinking: Transform the Business of Your Life and the Life of Your Business'' with Colin Crook and Robert E. Gunther * 2007 ''Competing in a Flat World: Building Enterprises for a Borderless World'' with Victor K. Fung and William K. Fung
=== Articles ===
* 1968 Yoram Wind, "The Determinants of Vendor Selection: The Evaluation Function Approach," ''Journal of Purchasing and Materials,'' 1968, pp 29–41 * 1970 {{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3149637 |jstor=3149637 |title=Industrial Source Loyalty |journal=Journal of Marketing Research |volume=7 |issue=4 |pages=450 |year=1970 |last1=Wind |first1=Yoram }} * 1972 {{cite journal |doi=10.1108/EUM0000000005120 |title=International market segmentation |journal=European Journal of Marketing |volume=6 |pages=17 |year=1972 |last1=Wind |first1=Yoram |last2=Douglas |first2=Susan P. }} * 1973 Yoram Wind, "A New Procedure for Concept Evaluation," ''Journal of Marketing,'' Vol. 37, No. 4 (Oct., 1973), pp. 2–11, Stable URL: https://www.jstor.org/stable/1250352 * 1974 {{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0019-8501(74)90025-X |title=Industrial market segmentation |journal=Industrial Marketing Management |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=153 |year=1974 |last1=Wind |first1=Yoram |last2=Cardozo |first2=Richard N. }} * 1976 Yoram Wind and Henry J. Claycamp, "Planning Product Line Strategy: A Matrix Approach," ''Journal of Marketing,'' Vol. 40, No. 1, 1976, pp. 2–9 Stable URL: https://www.jstor.org/stable/1250669 * 1978 {{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3150580 |jstor=3150580 |title=Issues and Advances in Segmentation Research |journal=Journal of Marketing Research |volume=15 |issue=3 |pages=317 |year=1978 |last1=Wind |first1=Yoram }} * 1980 {{cite journal |doi=10.1108/EUM0000000004904 |title=Conceptual and Methodological Issues in Organisational Buying Behaviour |journal=European Journal of Marketing |volume=14 |issue=5/6 |pages=239 |year=1980 |last1=Wind |first1=Yoram P. |last2=Thomas |first2=Robert J. }} * 1981 Phipps, A., Carroll, J.D. and Wind, Y.J., "Overlapping Clustering: A New Method for Product Positioning," ''Journal of Marketing Research,'' Vol. 18, No. 3 1981, pp. 310–317 * 1983 {{cite journal |doi=10.2307/1251490 |jstor=1251490 |title=Marketing Strategy: New Directions for Theory and Research |journal=Journal of Marketing |volume=47 |issue=2 |pages=12 |year=1983 |last1=Wind |first1=Yoram |last2=Robertson |first2=Thomas S. }} * 1988 {{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0737-6782(88)90014-8 |title=New product development process: A perspective for reexamination |journal=Journal of Product Innovation Management |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=304 |year=1988 |last1=Wind |first1=Y }} * 2002 {{cite journal |doi=10.1002/dir.10009 |title=Convergence marketing |journal=Journal of Interactive Marketing |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=64 |year=2002 |last1=Wind |first1=Yoram |last2=Mahajan |first2=Vijay }} * 2008 Yoram Wind, "A Plan to Invent the Marketing We Need Today," ''Sloan Management Review,'' 49.4, 2008, pp 21–28
=== Book Chapters === * Yoram Wind, "Positioning Analysis and Strategy," in: George Day and Robin Wensley, ''The Interface of Marketing Strategy,'' JAI Press, 1990 * Yoram (Jerry) Wind and Paul E. Green, "Some Conceptual, Measurement, and Analytical Problems in Life Style Research," Chapter 4 in: William S Wells (ed), ''Lifestyle and Psychographics,'' American Marketing Association [Marketing Classics Press], 2011, pp 99–125 * Yoram Wind and Vijay Mahajan, "The Challenge of Digital Marketing," Chapter 1 in: Yoram (Jerry) Wind, Vijay Mahajan (eds), ''Digital Marketing: Global Strategies from the World's Leading Experts,'' Wiley, 2011

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = John L. Crain |image = Crain John 2010Jan15 f.JPG |image_size = 240px |caption = |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1960}} |birth_place = [[Franklinton, Louisiana]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Hammond, Louisiana|Hammond]], [[Louisiana]] |citizenship = |nationality = {{flag|United States}} |ethnicity = |fields = [[Accounting]] |workplaces = [[Southeastern Louisiana University]] |predecessor=[[Randy Moffett]] |alma_mater = [[University of Mississippi]]
[[Southeastern Louisiana University]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = Southeastern Louisiana University president
Business professor
Prolific author |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = Southeastern Louisiana University President's Award for Excellence in Research 1994 |religion = [[United Methodist Church|Methodist]] |signature = |footnotes = }}'''John Luther Crain''' (born 1960, [[Franklinton, Louisiana]]) is [[president]] of [[Southeastern Louisiana University]] at [[Hammond, Louisiana|Hammond]], having been appointed to the position on 2009 February 17 by the Board of Supervisors of the [[University of Louisiana System]]. He succeeded [[Randy Moffett]].{{cite journal |url = http://www.c100la.org/who-we-are/member-profiles/john-l.-crain/ |magazine = C100 Louisiana |title = John L. Crain |date = 2009-02-17 |accessdate = 2012-01-06 }} Jordan Blum, [http://www.2theadvocate.com/news/39764857.html "System board approves Crain for SLU president"] in [[The Advocate (Baton Rouge, Louisiana)|''Advocate'' (Baton Rouge)]], 2009 February 18, p. 9A. [http://blog.nola.com/ponchatoulatimes/2009/02/john_l_crain_named_southeaster.html "John L. Crain named Southeastern's 14th president"] posted by the ''Ponchatoula Times'' on nola.com, 2009 February 18 (accessed 2009 June 12). ==Education== Crain, a 1978 graduate of [[Franklinton High School (Louisiana)|Franklinton High School, Louisiana]],{{cite web|title=Biography - Dr. John L. Crain|url=http://www.southeastern.edu/admin/president/biography/index.html|website=Southeastern Louisiana University|accessdate=11 November 2016}} holds [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] and [[MBA]] degrees from Southeastern and received a [[Ph.D.]] in [[accounting|accountancy]] from the [[University of Mississippi]].[http://www.selu.edu/admin/rec_reg/university_catalogue/current/general/pdf/faculty_instruction.pdf Southeastern ''General Catalogue'' faculty listing.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201112922/http://www.selu.edu/admin/rec_reg/university_catalogue/current/general/pdf/faculty_instruction.pdf |date=2008-12-01 }} He is an inactive [[Certified Public Accountant|CPA]] and an accomplished [[pianist]]. [http://www.selu.edu/admin/president/index.html Statement on the Southeastern Louisiana University web site.] [[File:2015-04-30 John Crain King Alexander.jpg|thumb|left|320px|Crain (left), listens while [[F. King Alexander]], chancellor of [[Louisiana State University]] and president of the [[LSU System]], responds to questions about funding for Louisiana's public universities, during a panel hosted by the [[Hammond, Louisiana|Greater Hammond Chamber of Commerce]].]] ==Researcher & administrator== Crain previously served as [[interim]] president, [[Provost (education)|provost]], [[vice president]] for academic affairs, [[accounting]] [[Academic department|department]] head, president of the [[Academic senate#United States|Faculty Senate]], and [[tenure]]d professor of accounting. He began full-time employment as an [[assistant professor]] of accounting at Southeastern in 1987 and held his first administrative position as interim director of the University's [[Small Business Administration#Organizational structure|Small Business Development Center]].[http://www.ulsystem.net/index.cfm?md=newsroom&tmp=detail&articleID=291 Announcement on the University of Louisiana System web site.] From a pool of 19 international applicants, the five semifinalists for the position were finalists Crain and [http://www.ttu.edu/administration/studentaffairs/ Michael] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215193319/http://www.ttu.edu/administration/studentaffairs/ |date=2009-02-15 }} [[Michael Shonrock|Shonrock]], [[Linda L. M. Bennett]], [[Nick Bruno]], and [[Karen A. White]], per [http://www.nbc33tv.com/news/five-finalists-named-slu-presidency "Five finalists named for Southeastern Louisiana University presidency"] as reported by [[WVLA]] Television Channel 33 ([[NBC-TV]] affiliate in [[Baton Rouge]]). See also René Abadie, [http://www.selu.edu/news_media/news_releases/2009/feb/crain.html John L. Crain Named Southeastern's 14th President;] and Kia Hill Hayes, [http://www.nola.com/timespic/stories/index.ssf?/base/news-6/1234938150272770.xml&coll=1 "Interim chief wins presidency . . ."] in ''[[Times-Picayune]]'' ([[New Orleans]]), 2009 February 18, Saint Tammany Edition, p. B4; and [http://hammondstar.com/articles/2009/02/20/opinion/editorials/9159.txt "Southeastern's new president"] in [[Daily Star (Hammond)|''Daily Star'']] ([[Hammond, Louisiana]]), 2009 February 18, p. 4A. In 1992 Crain received the Southeastern President's Award for Excellence in [[Research]]''';''' by 2009, on being named president, he had authored 63 [[refereed journal]] articles. [http://www.selu.edu/admin/president/index.html Statement on the Southeastern Louisiana University web site.] [[File:2015-05-06 John Crain at Faculty Senate.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Southeastern President John Crain addresses the Faculty Senate about the Fiscal Year 2016 budget.]] ==Challenges== Crain's accounting background appeared well matched to the challenges he soon faced as president, in that Louisiana's public institutions of higher education confronted unprecedented budget cuts and looming budget cuts.Don Ellzey, Leaner university: Crain expects more budget cuts will be "very unpopular" in ''Daily Star'' (Hammond, Louisiana), 2010 January 15, pp. 1A, 5A (web version = [http://www.hammondstar.com/articles/2010/01/15/top_stories/education/5933.txt Budget cuts won't be popular, says Crain], accessed 2010 January 16). In an article in the student newspaper, Crain announced mid-academic year eliminations of 35 positions''';''' expecting "even deeper cuts in the future," Crain said: :These changes would almost certainly involve the elimination of programs, including academic programs, and the termination of some tenured faculty. Despite the challenges we have dealt with and may still face, we remain absolutely committed to the success of our students and the ongoing viabillity of the university, albeit in what may be a smaller scope and scale.Budget Cuts Take Toll on Campus Jobs" in [[Southeastern Louisiana University#Lion's Roar|''Lion's Roar'']] (Southeastern Louisiana University), Volume 81 Issue 17 (2010 January 17), p. 1 (not online). See similar statements by [[University of Louisiana at Monroe]] president [[Nick Bruno#Challenges|Nick Bruno]] Crain is involved in Southeastern's [[fundraising]].{{cite news |date = 2011-01-11 |url = http://www.selu.edu/news_media/news_releases/2010/dec/entergy_grant.html |title = Grants/philanthropy |newspaper = Baton Rouge Business Report |volume = 29 |issue = 11 |page = 43 |accessdate = 2011-01-20 }} [[Entergy Corporation]]'s [[charitable foundation]], represented by Craig Schimpf, gave $10,000 to Southeastern's Department of English for the Department's program in [[publishing]] studies, the check being received by Crain together with [[academic department|department head]] David Hanson and Southeastern's Senior Director of Development Katherine Hufstetler Rose. ==Notes== [[File:2009Dec12 Southeastern Louisiana University Center commencement.JPG|thumb|right|420px|Graduation ceremony in [[University Center (Southeastern Louisiana)|Southeastern's University Center]], 2009 December 12, Dr John Crain presiding.]] {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crain, John}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:American classical pianists]] [[Category:American male pianists]] [[Category:American educators]] [[Category:American organists]] [[Category:American university and college presidents]] [[Category:Louisiana Republicans]] [[Category:People from Hammond, Louisiana]] [[Category:People from Franklinton, Louisiana]] [[Category:Southeastern Louisiana University]] [[Category:Southeastern Louisiana University alumni]] [[Category:University of Mississippi alumni]] [[Category:American United Methodists]] [[Category:20th-century American pianists]]

revision.text:
'''Leopold vel Liber Landsberg''' (10 June 1861 in [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] – 4 June 1935 in [[Łódź]], Poland), Jewish industrialist in Russia and Poland.
He was the youngest son of Mendel Landsberg, a tradesman in Warsaw, and Laia Lewin. His elder brethren [[Hilary Landsberg]] (1834–1898) and [[Alexander Landsberg]] (1859–1928) were clothing manufacturers in [[Tomaszów Mazowiecki]].
In 1885, Leopold Landsberg settled in Łódź and opened his factory (at Lonkowa Street), producing female clothing. By World War I, goods were selling to Russian markets. In 1905, as many as 70 workers employed in his factory. He was a treasurer of the Union of the Łódź Manufacturers. He belonged to the owners of the Joint-Stock Company of Cloth Factories in Tomaszów Mazowiecki.
After World War I, Leopold Landsberg's factory called “the Mechanical Weaving Mill of Wool Products” (in Polish “Tkalnia Mechaniczna Wyrobów Wełnianych”) was situated at Srodmiejska Street. Many wool goods were selling in local (Polish) market.
He was a president of the Jewish Association for Caring of the Sicks “Bykur Cholim”.
He died in Łódź and was buried in the Jewish Cemetery in Łódź at Bracka Street (Left side, Section D, tomb No. 107). His wife Sara (Sura) Salomea Hirschberg (1861–1944), daughter of Yehuda and Rayzla née Birnbaum, was buried in the neighbouring grave (No. 106).
== Bibliography == * Andrzej Kempa, Marek Szukalak, ''The Biographical Dictionary of the Jews from Lodz'', Lodz 2006: Oficyna Bibliofilów and Fundacja Monumentum Iudaicum Lodzense, {{ISBN|83-87522-83-X}}, pp. 149–150 (Leopold Landsberg’s biographical note).
{{DEFAULTSORT:Landsberg, Leopold}} [[Category:People from Łódź]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Warsaw]] [[Category:Polish Jews]] [[Category:Polish businesspeople]] [[Category:1861 births]] [[Category:1935 deaths]]
{{Poland-bio-stub}}

{{About|the Irish law firm|other uses of the term|Matheson (disambiguation)}} {{coord|53.345528|N|6.234958|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox law firm | firm_name = Matheson | firm_logo = [[File:Matheson company logo.png|150px]] | headquarters = 70 Sir John Rogerson's Quay, Grand Canal Dock, Dublin 2, D02 R296, [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]] | num_offices = 5 offices in 3 countries (Dublin, London, New York, San Francisco, Palto Alto) | num_lawyers= 86 partners | num_employees = 670 | practice_areas = [[Tax law]] | key_people = Michael Jackson
{{small|Managing Partner}} | revenue = €115 million {{small|2016 est.}} | profit_per_equity_partner = | date_founded = 1825
{{small|only 14 partners in 1991}} | company_type = [[Limited liability partnership]] | homepage = {{URL|https://www.matheson.com/}} }} [[File:2013 launch of the Irish Debt Securities Association (IDSA).jpg|thumb|260px|Irish Debt Securities Association (IDSA) launch in 2013 with Minister [[Richard Bruton]], IDSA CEO Gary Palmer, and IDSA Chairman Turlough Galvin of Matheson's Tax Practice.]] [[File:Matheson Foundation honours 150 young students.jpg|thumb|260px|Matheson Foundation Chairman Turlough Galvin, and Irish [[Taoiseach]] [[Leo Varadkar]], honour 150 children from the Centre for Talented Youth Ireland (CTYI) in 2016.]] '''Matheson''' (previously '''Matheson Ormsby Prentice'''), is an Irish [[law firm]] partnership based in the [[International Financial Services Centre]] in Dublin, which specialises in U.S. multinational tax schemes (e.g. for clients in Ireland such as Microsoft and Google), and tax structuring of special purpose vehicles (e.g. [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110 securitisation SPVs]]). Matheson is estimated to be Ireland's 4th–largest corporate law firm, and Europe's 27th–largest corporate law firm (by revenue).{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/big-seven-irish-law-firms-earned-720m-last-year-36238417.html|title='Big Seven' Irish law firms earned €720m last year|publisher=Irish Independent|date=18 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/retail-and-services/cantillon-are-there-now-only-three-law-firms-left-in-the-big-four-1.2231114|title=Cantillon: Are there now only three law firms left in the ‘big four’?|publisher=Irish Times|date=30 May 2015}} Matheson state in the [[:de:International Tax Review|International Tax Review]] that their tax department is: "significantly the largest tax practice group amongst Irish law firms".Our tax department is significantly the largest tax practice group amongst Irish law firms. {{cite web|url=https://www.matheson.com/legal-services/tax-lawyers|title=Matheson Ireland Profile|publisher=International Tax Review 2017|date=2017}} ==Development== While Matheson's website traces their history back to 1825 and that their offices were burnt in the Irish [[Easter Rising]] of 1916,{{cite web|url=https://www.matheson.com/about-us| title = Matheson history| publisher= Matheson | date=2018}} it wasn't until after the creation and initial development of Dublin's [[International Financial Services Centre]] (or IFSC) that Matheson Ormsby Prentice (or "MOPs", as it was called) emerged as a small but standalone law firm with 14 partners and over 50 solicitors (or lawyers) in 1991.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/matheson-ormsby-prentice-wins-award-1.1051641| title = Matheson Ormsby Prentice wins award | publisher=Irish Times | date=25 February 2002}} It moved to its current [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] offices, 70 Sir John Rodgerson's Quay in 2007,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/legal-firm-s-hq-on-the-market-1.1196456| title = Legal firm's HQ on the market| publisher=Irish Times | date=21 April 2007}} and rebranded to "Matheson" in October 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.thelawyer.com/issues/online-october-2012/irelands-mop-drops-ormsby-prentice-to-become-matheson/| title = Ireland’s MOP drops Ormsby Prentice to become Matheson| publisher=The Lawyer | date=25 October 2012}} While A&L Goodbody and Arthur Cox still lead Irish corporate law, Matheson has grown with the rise in the [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] to become one of Ireland's "big four" corporate law firms (with McCannFitzgerald). Matheson focuses on the two legal areas most associated with the [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]], namely tax structuring for U.S. multinationals (e.g. Microsoft, Google, Pepsi, all Matheson clients), and creating [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]]–domiciled corporate tax structures and tax efficient vehicles for various asset management and asset financing activities (particularly [[securitisation]] special purpose vehicles, which the [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] leads in the EU–28).{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/ireland-is-top-eurozone-jurisdiction-for-secretive-spvs-36047198.html|title=Ireland is top Eurozone jurisdiction for SPVs|publisher=Irish Independent|date=19 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.idsa.ie/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/IDSA_Securitisation-Industry-in-Ireland.pdf|title=Ireland: The Leading European Jurisdiction for SPVs, Structured Finance and Securitised Structures|publisher=Irish Debt Securities Association|date=2016}} In 2013 Matheson founded the '''Irish Debt Securities Association''' (or IDSA), which acts as the industry lobby group for the [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)]] (the [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]]'s main [[securitisation]] structure).{{cite web|url=https://www.matheson.com/news-and-insights/article/matheson-welcomes-irish-debt-securities-association| title = Matheson welcomes Irish Debt Securities Association| publisher=Matheson|date=19 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/lobby-group-says-tax-loophole-closure-may-dampen-nama-sales-1.2783286| title = Lobby group says tax loophole closure may dampen Nama sales| publisher=Irish Times|date=8 September 2016}} Like [[Feargal O'Rourke]] in [[PriceWaterhouseCoopers]] (Ireland [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]]), Matheson has been an active lobbyist for expanding various Irish legal structures and amending taxation controls to help grow the [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]], which can lead to conflict.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/vulture-funds-using-shadow-lobbying-system-burton-says-1.2961441| title = Vulture funds using ‘shadow’ lobbying system, Burton says| publisher=Irish Times|date=2 February 2017}} Matheson's leadership in [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] tax structures (or [[Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|IP–based BEPS tools]], and [[Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Debt–based BEPS tools]]), makes makes them a noted industry commentator.Also discussed was the need for Ireland to continually review and update the legal framework to reflect the speed of change and to cater for tangible assets so they are ‘fit for purpose’.{{cite web|url=https://businessandfinance.com/news/matheson-increasing-ip-onshoring-ireland-brexit-benefit/| title = Matheson identifies increasing onshoring of Intellectual Property tax structures to Ireland as Brexit benefit| publisher=Business & Finance|date=27 March 2018}} ==Awards== {{see also|Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland#Low tax economy}} Matheson's leadership in the area of U.S. multinational tax planning in Ireland, a jurisdiction which is ranked as one of the world's top [[corporate haven]]s (see [[Corporate haven#Corporate tax haven lists|corporate tax haven lists]]),{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Fireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401|title=Ireland is the world’s biggest corporate ‘tax haven’, say academics|quote=Study claims State shelters more multinational profits than the entire Caribbean|publisher=Irish Times|date=13 June 2018}} has seen Matheson win major awards from the international corporate tax planning industry, including: * Ireland Transfer Pricing Firm of the Year, [[:de:International Tax Review|International Tax Review]] 2018{{cite web|url=https://www.irishlegal.com/12692/matheson-named-transfer-pricing-firm-of-the-year/|title=Matheson wins transfer pricing firm of the year|publisher=Irish Legal News|date=21 May 2018}} * Ireland’s Most Innovative Law Firm, [[Financial Times]] Innovative Lawyer Awards 2017{{cite web|url=http://www.irishlegal.com/8835/mccann-fitzgerald-and-matheson-take-home-innovative-lawyer-awards/|title=Matheson and McCanns win at FT Innovative Lawyer Awards|publisher=Irish Legal News|date=6 October 2017}} * European Financial Services Tax Deal of the Year, [[:de:International Tax Review|International Tax Review]] 2017{{cite web|url=http://www.internationaltaxreview.com/Article/3718472/Awards-Archive/European-Tax-Awards-2017-Winners-announced.html#/EuropeanTaxFirmoftheYear|title=European Financial Service Tax Deal of the Year 2017|publisher=International Tax Review|date=11 July 2017}} * Ireland Tax Firm of the Year, [[:de:International Tax Review|International Tax Review]] 2016 * European M&A Tax Firm of the Year, [[:de:International Tax Review|International Tax Review]] 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.irishlegal.com/4388/matheson-celebrates-double-win-at-european-tax-awards-2016/|title=Matheson celebrates double win at European Tax Awards 2016|publisher=Irish Legal News|date=30 May 2016}} ==Criticism== ===U.S. multinational tax schemes=== {{See also|Double Irish arrangement|Corporate tax haven}} Matheson's leadership in the Irish tax strategies of U.S. multinationals, (or [[BEPS]] tools), has attracted attention from U.S. media over the years. In 2005, the Wall Street Journal ran a story on how Microsoft used an Irish subsidiary called "Round Ireland One" to avoid billions in U.S. taxes which was structured and registered in Matheson's offices (was then Matheson Ormsby Prentice, or MOPS).{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB113132761685289706| title=Irish Subsidiary Lets Microsoft Slash Taxes in U.S. and Europe| publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=7 November 2005|quote=Round Island's legal address is in the headquarters of a Dublin law firm, Matheson Ormsby Prentice, that advertises its expertise in helping multinational companies use Ireland to shelter income from taxes.|author=Glenn R. Simpson}}{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/cms/upload/pdf/WSJ_-_Microsoft_slashes_taxes_in_US_and_EU_through_Irish_subsidiary_-_7_NOV_2005.pdf| title=TAX JUSTICE NETWORK: Irish Subsidiary Lets Microsoft Slash Taxes in U.S. and Europe| publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=7 November 2005}} In 2013 the Wall Street Journal ran another investigation showing that the scale of U.S. operations in Ireland, using Matheson registered tax structures, had dramatically increased from 2005.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/dublin-moves-to-block-controversial-tax-gambit-1381890312| title=Dublin Moves to Block Controversial Tax Gambit|quote=At least 125 major U.S. companies have registered several hundred subsidiaries or investment funds at 70 Sir John Rogerson’s Quay, a seven–story building in Dublin’s docklands, according to a review of government and corporate records by The Wall Street Journal. The common thread is the building’s primary resident: Matheson, an Irish law firm that specializes in ways companies can use Irish tax law.|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=15 October 2013}} These strategies has seen Ireland labelled as one of the world's largest [[corporate tax haven]]s,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Fireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401|title=Ireland is the world’s biggest corporate ‘tax haven’, say academics|quote=Study claims State shelters more multinational profits than the entire Caribbean|publisher=Irish Times|date=13 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|title=Zucman:Corporations Push Profits Into Corporate Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Gabrial Zucman Study Says|quote=The new research draws on data from countries such as Ireland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands that hadn’t previously been collected.|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=10 June 2018}} and blacklisted by Brazil.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ireland-brazil-funds/blacklisted-by-brazil-dublin-funds-find-new-ways-to-invest-idUSL8N1MK2NX|title=Blacklisted by Brazil, Dublin funds find new ways to invest|publisher=Reuters|date=20 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/ireland-no-tax-haven-us-authorities-told-35565554.html|title=Oregon Department of Revenue made a recommendation that Ireland be included as a 'listed jurisdiction' or tax haven|publisher=Irish Independent|date=26 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2017/04/10/tax-haven-blacklisting-13-latin-american-countries/|title=Tax haven blacklisting in Latin America|publisher=Tax Justice Network|date=6 April 2017}} Like other tax law firms in the [[International Financial Services Centre]], Matheson has openly marketed [[Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|IP–based BEPS tools]] with [[Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland#Effective tax rate (ETR)|effective tax rates]] of under 3%.{{cite web|url=http://www.matheson.com/images/uploads/documents/China_Article_-_March_2013.pdf|title=Ireland as a European gateway jurisdiction for China – outbound and inbound investments | quote= The tax deduction can be used to achieve an effective tax rate of 2.5% on profits from the exploitation of the IP purchased. Provided the IP is held for five years, a subsequent disposal of the IP will not result in a clawback.|publisher=Matheson|date=March 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/377485537/Maples-and-Calder-Ireland-Intellectual-Property-2018|title=Maples and Calder Irish Intellectual Property Tax Regime - 2.5% Effective Tax| quote=Structure 1: The profits of the Irish company will typically be subject to the corporation tax rate of 12.5% if the company has the requisite level of substance to be considered trading. The tax depreciation and interest expense can reduce the effective rate of tax to a minimum of 2.5%.|publisher=[[Maples and Calder]]|date=February 2018}} Mainstream U.S. media channels have singled out Matheson in Dublin, as a significant centre for U.S. multinational tax strategies.{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/americansfortaxfairness/nine-little-places-that-are-home-for-one-million-c-gsk9| title=Nine Little Places That Are Home For One Million Corporations| publisher=Buzzfeed|date=30 October 2013}} In this regard, Matheson is akin to the situation of Irish PwC Managing Partner [[Feargal O'Rourke]], whose development of the [[double Irish]] [[Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|IP–based BEPS tool]], has also made him the subject of investigative pieces by the U.S. financial media.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-10-28/man-making-ireland-tax-avoidance-hub-globally-proves-local-hero| title=Man Making Ireland Tax Avoidance Hub Proves Local Hero | publisher=Bloomberg News|date=28 October 2013}} Bloomberg recognise that O'Rourke, while being at the vanguard of legitimate but aggressive U.S. multinational tax planning, is considered a "hero" in Ireland.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/controversial-tax-strategies-brainchild-of-orourkes-son-29721835.html| title=Controversial tax strategies brainchild of O'Rourke's son| publisher=Irish Independent|date=3 November 2013}} ===Section 110 tax schemes and children's charities=== {{main article|Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)#Abuses}} In 2016, Matheson was criticised in the Irish media when it was revealed that U.S. [[distressed debt]] funds (known pejoratively as "vulture funds" in the Irish media),{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/how-to-get-vulture-funds-to-pay-tax-1.2740830|title=How to get vulture funds to pay tax|publisher=Irish Times|date=1 August 2016}} had used the services of Irish [[International Financial Services Centre]] securitisation law firms to avoid billions in Irish taxes,{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/stephen-donnelly-tax-avoidance-anomaly-means-pain-for-taxpayers-34906487.html|title=Tax avoidance could run to billions|publisher=Irish Independent|date=24 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://stephendonnelly.ie/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Closing-Down-Section-110-for-Vulture-Funds.pdf | title=WHY LETTING SECTION 110 SPVS OPERATE IN THE IRISH DOMESTIC ECONOMY WILL DAMAGE OUR TAX BASE AND OUR REPUTATION AS A ‘LOW-TAX’ ECONOMY | publisher=Stephen Donnelly (Dail Submission)|date=September 2016}} on Irish distressed assets by using [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Irish Section 110 SPVs]].{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/loophole-lets-firms-earning-millions-pay-250-tax-d%C3%A1il-told-1.3145769|title=Loophole lets firms earning millions pay €250 tax, Dáil told|publisher=Irish Times|date=6 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/vulture-funds-2-3176030-Jan2017/|title=Vulture funds pay just €8,000 in tax on €10 billion of assets|publisher=thejournal.ie|date=8 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.businesspost.ie/news/revealed-vulture-funds-paid-e20k-tax-assets-e20bn-375290|title=Revealed: How vulture funds paid €20k in tax on assets of €20bn|publisher=The Sunday Business Post|date=8 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/dublin-unit-of-us-hedge-fund-with-8bn-assets-pays-125-tax-1.2756124?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Fdublin-unit-of-us-hedge-fund-with-8bn-assets-pays-125-tax-1.2756124|title=Dublin unit of US hedge fund with $8bn assets pays $125 tax|publisher=Irish Times|date=15 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/cerberus-paid-1-900-tax-on-77m-project-eagle-profits-1.2885720?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Fcommercial-property%2Fcerberus-paid-1-900-tax-on-77m-project-eagle-profits-1.2885720|title=Cerberus paid €1,900 tax on €77m Project Eagle profits|publisher=Irish Times|date=29 November 2016}} These structures were created so [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] law firms could administer global securitisation transactions.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/how-do-vulture-funds-exploit-tax-loopholes-1.2832688?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Fcommercial-property%2Fhow-do-vulture-funds-exploit-tax-loopholes-1.2832688| title=How do vulture funds exploit tax loopholes?| publisher=Irish Times|date=17 October 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mhc.ie/uploads/Silver_Linings_Daragh_Bohan.pdf| title=Mason Hayes and Curran:Silver Linings from Ireland's Financial Clouds| publisher=Mason Hayes & Curran Law|date=May 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/only-lawyers-and-accountants-gain-from-irish-spvs-central-bank-35103770.html|title=Only lawyers and accountants gain from Irish 'SPVs' - Central Bank|publisher=Irish Independent|date=5 October 2016}} Matheson featured as one of the most frequently used advisors by the U.S. distressed debt funds (with A&L Goodbody).{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/vultures-minimise-their-tax-bills-as-state-now-appears-to-have-delivered-the-sale-of-the-century-34981270.html|title='Vultures' minimise their tax bills – as State now appears to have delivered the sale of the century|publisher=Irish Independent|date=21 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.davidmcwilliams.ie/vulture-funds-rub-salt-into-the-carcass-of-this-country/|title=Vulture funds rub salt into the carcass of this country|publisher=David McWilliams Sunday Business Post|date=1 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://emmaclancy.com/2016/07/30/how-do-vulture-funds-pay-practically-no-tax-in-ireland/|title=How do vulture funds manage to pay practically no tax in Ireland?|publisher=Emma Clancy|date=30 July 2016}} The affair escalated into the "[[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)#Abuses|vulture fund tax avoidance]]" scandal,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/state-scrutinising-matheson-s-use-of-tax-loopholes-1.2736631|title=State scrutinising Matheson’s use of tax loopholes|publisher=Irish Times|date=28 July 2016}} when it was found Matheson used three in-house children's charities (Eurydice, Medb and Badb),{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/vulture-funds-using-charities-to-avoid-paying-tax-says-donnelly-1.2722370?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fnews%2Fpolitics%2Foireachtas%2Fvulture-funds-using-charities-to-avoid-paying-tax-says-donnelly-1.2722370|title=Vulture funds using charities to avoid paying tax, says Donnelly|publisher=Irish Times|date=14 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://stephendonnelly.ie/why-would-a-so-called-vulture-fund-be-owned-by-a-childrens-charity/|title=Why would a Vulture Fund own a Children's Charity|publisher=Dail Eireann|date=24 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/barnardos-deny-receiving-funding-from-owner-of-vulture-fund-35242922.html|title=Barnardos deny receiving funding from owner of vulture fund, Matheson Foundation|publisher=Irish Independent|date=24 November 2016}} to make the [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Irish Section 110 SPV]] work in an Irish domestic setting (known as "[[Orphan structure|orphaning]]").{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/wealthy-firms-using-charitable-status-to-avoid-paying-taxes-409994.html|title=Wealthy firms ‘using charitable status to avoid paying taxes’|publisher=Irish Examiner|date=13 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/law-firm-defends-use-of-charities-to-help-hedge-funds-cut-tax-bills-1.2329919?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Flaw-firm-defends-use-of-charities-to-help-hedge-funds-cut-tax-bills-1.2329919|title=Law firm defends use of charities to help hedge funds cut tax bills|publisher=Irish Times|date=27 August 2015}} This was a purpose for which Finance Minister [[Michael Noonan (Fine Gael politician)|Michael Noonan]] acknowledged "the Section 110 legislation was not set up for". The affair became a major Irish scandal{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/opinion/comment/how-did-the-government-shaft-mortgage-holders-and-taxpayers-in-one-fell-swoop-34870748.html|title=How did the Government shaft mortgage holders and taxpayers in one fell swoop?|publisher=Irish Independent|date=10 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/opinion/columnists/colette-browne/vulture-funds-are-feasting-taxfree-on-carcass-of-our-property-crash-35005936.html|title=Vulture funds are feasting tax–free on carcass of our property crash|publisher=Irish Independent|date=30 August 2016}} and was reported in the international media.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37287182|title=Forget Apple: Ireland's other taxing issue|publisher=BBC News|date=6 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/619c9bde-74f3-11e6-bf48-b372cdb1043a|title=Ireland confronts another tax scandal closer to home|publisher=Financial Times|date=11 September 2016}} The Irish State closed the loopholes,{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/loophole-allowing-vulture-funds-to-pay-almost-no-irish-profit-tax-shut-35026753.html|title=Loophole allowing Vulture Funds to pay almost no Irish profit tax shut|publisher=Irish Independent|date=16 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2016/0906/814471-revenue-nama-foi/|title=Government moves to amend Section 110 to close tax loophole used by vulture funds|publisher=RTE News|date=6 September 2016}} and prohibit Irish charities from being used in tax avoidance structures.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/retail-and-services/regulator-rejects-claim-matheson-charities-financial-services-ancillary-1.3064287|title=Irish Charities Regulator rejects Matheson Charities in Section 110 SPVs|publisher=Irish Times|date=28 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/matheson-stops-using-charities-to-help-clients-avoid-tax-1.2959974|title=Matheson stops using charities to help clients avoid tax|publisher=Irish Times|date=27 February 2018}} ===Panama papers exposure=== {{see also|Panama papers|List of people named in the Panama Papers}} It was revealed in the Irish section of the [[panama papers]] leak of 2016, that a Senior Matheson Partner, Stanley Watson, had established an offshore tax structure with [[Mossack Fonseca]]'s help in Cyprus, to reduce his tax bill on moving to London to set up the Matheson London office.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/retail-and-services/senior-matheson-figure-set-up-cyprus-firm-to-reduce-tax-bill-1.2596988|title=Senior Matheson figure set up Cyprus firm to reduce tax bill|publisher=Irish Times|date=4 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/what-the-panama-papers-tell-us-about-ireland-1.2603444|title=What the Panama Papers tell us about Ireland|publisher=Irish Times|date=9 April 2016}} A woman in the Matheson Dublin office, was helping handle the correspondence to establish the structure.. The affair caused further embarrassment for Matheson when Stanley Watson's Isle of Man advisor was recorded as describing Matheson to [[Mossack Fonseca]] as "our biggest client". ==See also== {{Portal|Ireland}} *[[Double Irish arrangement|Double Irish, Single Malt, Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets ("CAIA")]] *[[Irish Financial Services Centre]] *[[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)]] *[[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)]] *[[Offshore magic circle]] *[[Ireland as a tax haven]] *[[Maples and Calder]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.matheson.com/|Matheson Official Website}} *{{Twitter|@MathesonLaw|Matheson}} *{{LinkedIn URL|https://www.linkedin.com/company/matheson1|Matheson}} *[http://www.idsa.ie/ Irish Debt Securities Association (Irish Section 110 SPV lobby group)] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Law in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Taxation in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Corporate taxation|Ireland]] [[Category:Economy of the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Tax avoidance]] [[Category:Corporate tax avoidance]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title = Millionaire |image = MillionaireBoxArtBBCMicro.jpg |caption = BBC Micro cover art |developer = [[John Hunt (games programmer)|John Hunt]] |publisher = [[Incentive Software]] |designer = |engine = |released = {{vgrelease|EU|[[1984 in video gaming|1984]]}} |genre = [[Business simulation game|Business simulation]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = [[ZX Spectrum]], [[Acorn Electron]], [[BBC Micro]] }}
{{About-distinguish2|the 1984 Incentive Software title|the stock-market simulation game of the same name release in the mid-1980s by Blue Chip Software of [[Canoga Park, California]].<ref name="pournelle198408">{{cite news | url=https://archive.org/stream/byte-magazine-1984-08/1984_08_BYTE_09-08_Modula-2#page/n317/mode/2up | title=Between Conventions | work=BYTE | date=Aug 1984 | accessdate=24 February 2016 | author=Pournelle, Jerry | pages=313}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1= Ditlea |first1= Steve |last2= Onosco |first2= Tim |last3= Kunkel |first3= Bill |author-link3= Bill Kunkel (gaming)|date= February 1985 |title= Random Access: Best Sellers/Recreation |journal= [[Video (magazine)|Video]]|publisher= Reese Communications|volume= 8|issue= 11|page= 35|issn= 0147-8907}}</ref>}}
'''''Millionaire''''' is a management game originally written for the [[ZX Spectrum]] by [[John Hunt (games programmer)|John Hunt]] and ported to the [[Acorn Electron]] and [[BBC Micro]].
== Gameplay == Millionaire is a text-based management game in which the player takes the role of a home-based games programmer who has written a program and must market it to the retailers. Starting with an investment of £500, you require this money to pay advertisers and tape duplication costs. Meanwhile, you must constantly write new games promote your products and keep a tight lid on costs. The style of game that could be programmed included:
* Arcade * Adventure * Strategy
The player then had to allocate 20 management points to spread amongst the following categories.
*1.Programming. *2.Presentation. *3.Original Ideas. *4.Maintain interest.
Other aspects of the game is a character called Honest Harry who could offer you deals such as cheap cassettes, which will lessen the cost of your distribution costs, or programs. Sometimes, these deals are not so good as the programs could be bugged or stolen, ultimately costing you dearly.
Progress in the game is monitored by observing the sales figures at the end of each month. If the player made enough money the a screenshot of a bigger and better house/office was displayed.
Chance played a part of the game, involving certain events which will affect your sales, such as a good review or someone digging up your past.
=== Objective === To become a software [[Millionaire]] and to avoid [[Bankruptcy]].
==Reception== {{expand section|date=February 2016}}
== Trivia == This game has some similarities to [[Software Star]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{WoS game|id=0003204|name=Millionaire}} *[http://www.gamefaqs.com/bbc/950260-millionaire/data ''Millionaire''] at [[GameFAQs]]
{{Incentive Software}}
[[Category:1984 video games]] [[Category:BBC Micro and Acorn Electron games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Europe-exclusive video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:ZX Spectrum games]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event | name = Mitzvah Day International | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_size = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | status = <!-- e.g. defunct, active, inactive ... --> | genre = Day of faith-based social action | date = November | begins = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|mm|dd}} --> | ends = <!-- {{end date|YYYY|mm|dd}} --> | frequency = Annual | venue = | location = United Kingdom | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | country = | years_active = <!-- {{age|YYYY|mm|dd}} Date of the first occurrence --> | first = 2005 | founder_name = Laura Marks | last = <!-- Date of most recent event; if the event will not be held again, use {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | prev = | next = | participants = 30,000 | attendance = | capacity = | area = | budget = | activity = | leader_name = | patron = | organised = <!-- "organized=" also works --> | filing = | people = | member = | sponsor = <!-- | or sponsors = --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | footnotes = }}
'''Mitzvah Day International''' is an annual day of faith-based social action that takes place in November each year, primarily in the [[United Kingdom]]. On Mitzvah Day each year, community groups and individuals undertake a range of [[Volunteering|volunteer]] projects for those in need in their local community. Organizations register with Mitzvah Day, which in turn helps match volunteers with local projects. The objective is to encourage people to give their time, rather than their money, to worthwhile local causes, whilst also creating deeper linkages within communities and supporting charities. In 2013, close to 30,000 people participated in Mitzvah Day around the world.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=2013-11-19 |title=In Pictures: Mitzvah Day 2013 |url=http://jewishnews.co.uk/in-pictures-mitzvah-day-2013/ |newspaper=Hendon & Finchley Times |location= |publisher=Times Series |accessdate=2013-11-20 }}</ref> Though based within the [[British Jews|UK's Jewish Community]], Mitzvah Day traditionally marks the first day of UK National Inter Faith Week,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.interfaithweek.org/index.php/events/events/extended-list-test?viewid=16&vmode=d&date=2013-11-17 |title=UK Inter Faith Week: Events for Sunday, November 17, 2013 |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=2013-11-17 |website=Inter Faith Week |publisher= |accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref> and as a result has expanded to include participants from other faith communities as well.<ref>{{cite news |last=Slater |first=Anna |date=2013-11-15 |title=Interfaith Mitzvah Day project in Whetstone |url=http://www.times-series.co.uk/news/10812704.Interfaith_Mitzvah_Day_project/ |newspaper=Hendon & Finchley Times |location= |publisher=Times Series |accessdate=2013-11-20 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Halkon |first=Ruth |date=2013-11-06 |title=Mitzvah Day and National Interfaith Week events in Aldenham and Radlett |url=http://www.borehamwoodtimes.co.uk/news/10790049.Gathering_together_to_make_the_community_better/ |newspaper=Borehamwood & Elstree Times |location= |publisher=Times Series |accessdate=2013-11-20 }}</ref> '[[Mitzvah]]' is the Hebrew biblical term for 'deed' or '[[613 mitzvot|commandment]]', which has come to mean 'good deed' or 'charitable act' in contemporary [[English Language|English]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/mitzvah |title=Mitzvah: definition |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=Miriam Webster Dictionary |publisher= |accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref>
The 2017 date is November 19.<ref>http://mitzvahday.org.uk/</ref>
== History == Mitzvah Day International was founded by Laura Marks in 2005, who, upon returning to her native UK from a period spent in [[Los Angeles]], decided to bring the 'Mitzvah Day' concept she became familiar with through the [[Temple Israel of Hollywood]] [[synagogue]] back to the UK. Though the Mitzvah Day she was familiar with (and most Mitzvah Days in the US) was based around a single community or [[Synagogue|congregation]], her concept for Mitzvah Day in the UK was to unite Jewish community and other groups around a single coordinated day of social action across the country. Mitzvah Day was originally associated with the [[Jewish Community Centre for London]], and became registered as an independent charity in the United Kingdom in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mitzvahday.org.uk/about-us.html |title=About Us |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=Mitzvah Day |publisher= |accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref>
== Endorsements == Mitzvah Day has been publicly endorsed by many public figures in the United Kingdom, including [[UK Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]],<ref name=threeleaders>{{cite news |last=Sharma |first=Suruchi |date=2011-11-11 |title=Three main party leaders back Mitzvah Day |url=http://www.times-series.co.uk/news/mitzvah/9359755.Three_main_party_leaders_back_Mitzvah_Day/ |newspaper=Hendon & Finchley Times |location= |publisher=Times Series |accessdate=2013-11-20 }}</ref> [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]] and [[Leader of the Liberal Democrats|Leader]] of the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] [[Nick Clegg]],<ref name=threeleaders /> [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Leader]] of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] [[Ed Miliband]]<ref name=threeleaders /> Former [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|UK Prime Minister]] [[Tony Blair]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Wolfisz |first=Francine |date=2010-11-19 |title=Tony Blair praises Mitzvah Day for "building bridges" between faiths |url=http://www.times-series.co.uk/news/mitzvah/8676992.Tony_Blair_praises_Mitzvah_Day_for__building_bridges__between_faiths/ |newspaper=Hendon & Finchley Times |location= |publisher=Times Series |accessdate=2013-11-20 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Blair |first=Tony |date=2010-11-18 |title=Faiths come together in joint action |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2010/nov/18/tony-blair-mitzvah-day |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |publisher= |accessdate=2013-11-20 }}</ref> [[London Mayor]] [[Boris Johnson]],<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=2011-11-21 |title=Boris Johnson's Mitzvah Day message |url=http://www.thejc.com/videos/news-videos/boris-johnsons-mitzvah-day-message |newspaper=The Jewish Chronicle |location=London |publisher= |accessdate=2013-11-20 }}</ref> [[Chief Rabbi of the United Kingdom]] [[Jonathan Sacks]], and [[The Archbishop of Canterbury]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Welby |first=Justin |date=2013-11-15 |title=As Archbishop of Canterbury, I'm a Mitzvah Day fan |url=http://www.thejc.com/comment-and-debate/comment/113231/as-archbishop-canterbury-im-a-mitzvah-day-fan |newspaper=The Jewish Chronicle |location=London |publisher= |accessdate=2013-11-20 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mitzvahday.org.uk/awards-and-endorsements.html |title=Awards and Endorsements |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=Mitzvah Day International |publisher= |accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref> It won a Prime Minister's [[Big Society]] Award in 2011<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bigsocietyawards.org/award-winners/mitzvah-day/ |title=Big Society Award Winners: 2013 |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=Big Society Awards |publisher= |accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/mitzvah-day-wins-prime-ministers-big-society-award |title=Mitzvah Day wins Prime Minister's Big Society Award |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=2011-11-30 |website=Big Society Awards, Press Release |publisher=Prime Minister's Office, 10 Downing Street |accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref>
== International expansion == Headquartered in [[London]], UK, the event has since spread to include participation from many international partners, primarily in [[Europe]], [[North America]], [[Israel]], [[Australia]], [[Brazil]], and [[Southern Africa]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mitzvahday.org.uk/around-the-world.html |title=Mitzvah Day Around The World |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=2011-11-30 |website=Mitzvah Day International |publisher= |accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref> In 2012, the name of the organization officially changed from 'Mitzvah Day' to 'Mitzvah Day International' to reflect the growing participation of community groups outside the UK.
